summary: Scope expanded/shifted to include building a standalone single-page interactive Valentine’s Day website (HTML + Tailwind CSS + JavaScript) with a light background, GIF-driven UI, dynamic Yes/No button behavior (No cycles phrases and scales buttons), GIF swap after several No clicks, and a Yes flow that clears the screen, shows a celebratory GIF + heading, and triggers confetti (canvas-confetti), with responsive mobile-first layout and cute Google Fonts.
architectural_notes: Project includes an ICP canister backend written in Motoko with generated Candid/TypeScript declaration bindings consumed by the React frontend.
Frontend is built with Vite + React + Tailwind and integrates shadcn/ui components and related lint/config tooling.
Authentication is implemented via Internet Identity with dedicated hooks/utilities for identity/session and actor creation.
Repository includes a reusable build-template workspace with Docker/deploy scripts and image processing scripts (resize/prune).
Standalone implementation should be plain HTML + Tailwind CSS + vanilla JS (no React/ICP dependency) and use canvas-confetti for the celebration effect.
Use a click counter (noCount) to drive No-button phrase cycling, GIF swapping, and Yes-button scaling per the provided formula (e.g., fontSize = (noCount * 20) + 16 + 'px').

Implement a Valentine proposal UI that matches the existing design: a single-screen Valentine page with a background image, hero image, and “Yes” / “No” buttons, where clicking “Yes” transitions to a success screen that keeps the same overall look and Valentine theme.
Ensure the proposal and success screens use the existing generated static image assets for the background, hero image, and heart icons from /assets/generated.

Update the Valentine proposal and success screens to visually match the look-and-feel of https://open-at-own-risk-mjf.caffeine.xyz as closely as possible (layout, typography, spacing, button styling, background treatment, and overall polish), while preserving the existing two-step flow (proposal -> success on Yes).

Keep the main question text exactly "Harshita, will you be my Valentine?" on the proposal screen and ensure the success screen copy still includes the exact text "Harshita, will you be my Valentine?" while updating any other surrounding copy to fit the referenced webpage’s tone and style (English only for any user-facing text).

Maintain use of the existing generated static assets via the centralized asset map (frontend/src/lib/valentineAssets.ts) while adjusting their presentation (e.g., sizing, cropping, overlays, filters, placement) as needed to match the referenced webpage’s design.

Update the proposal (initial) screen to a light, playful, minimalist aesthetic with a white or very light pink background, showing a cute greeting GIF at the top, centered question text that reads exactly "Will you be my Valentine?", and two centered buttons: "Yes" (pink/red) and "No" (gray).

Implement "No" button click behavior: each click increments a counter, cycles the "No" button label through an increasingly desperate phrase list (including at least: "Are you sure?", "Really?", "Think again!", "Last chance!", "Surely not?", "You're breaking my heart"), increases the "Yes" button size significantly, and decreases the "No" button size slightly on every click.

Swap the main GIF based on the "No" click count: start with a cute greeting GIF, then after a few "No" clicks switch to a clearly sad/crying animation. Implement the GIF selection in frontend state (e.g., by swapping the image src based on the counter).

Implement "Yes" button success flow: when "Yes" is clicked, replace the proposal UI with a success view that shows a celebratory GIF and a large heading that reads exactly "Knew you would say yes! ❤️", and trigger a confetti explosion using the canvas-confetti library.
Add cute typography via Google Fonts (use "Pacifico" or "Quicksand") and ensure the layout is mobile-first responsive with centered content and buttons across small screen sizes.
